claim: regardless of both building have 47 floor , the tour de la bourse take the title of the tallest building from the place ville marie in 1964 by a mere 6 / 20 m / ft difference
resp:
Here are the reasoning steps:
1. Identify the two buildings mentioned in the claim, tour de la bourse and place ville marie.
2. Find out when each building became the tallest (years as tallest) and the difference in their heights (height m / ft).
3. Determine if the specified year of height difference matches the year when one building took over as the tallest from the other.
4. Check if both buildings have 47 floors to verify the claim about their number of floors.

Based on the table, here are the relevant details:
- tour de la bourse was tallest from 1964 to 1992 with a height of 194/637 m / ft and has 47 floors (row index: 5).
- place ville marie was tallest from 1962 to 1964 with a height of 188/617 m / ft and also has 47 floors (row index: 4).

The difference in their heights is 6m/ft, which matches the specified year when tour de la bourse became the tallest. So, the claim is TRUE.

3. Check if only one building's height during that timeframe is greater than or equal to the heights of all other buildings in the table during their respective periods as the tallest.
4. If there is only one such building, then it can be said that from 1829 - 1928, this building was indeed the tallest and held the record for the most years as the tallest.

- There is only one building (Notre Dame Basilica) with this timeframe, so it was the tallest during that period.
